bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, June 5, 1942

div1.p: Hench comments on Wood's manuscript. He hopes that she will acknowledge the Reeds in her foreword.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, June 5, 1942
div1.opener:
June 5, 1942
Miss Laura Wood
230 South 19th Street
Philadelphia, Pa.
My dear Miss Wood:
div1.p:
I feel that I have let you down by delaying my reply so long, but I had
a very hectic time recently. I have just heard that I have passed my army exam-
ination but have no idea how soon I will be called to active duty.
I think your manuscript is excellent and I have very few comments to make.

list.item:
201: You say that the disease was carried in Spanish ships to the
Barbadoes in 1864. Then you continue as if in chronological sequence to mention
that it hit Havana in 1649. Is one of these dates wrong?

Page 202: You say one attack usually produced immunity. I thought that
one attack of true yellow fever always produced immunity and that the confusion
arose because people who thought they had had yellow fever occasionally later
got true yellow fever. Are you sure that the word “usually” should be left in?

Page 203: “The untended sick lay in the same room with the decomposing
dead until they died themselves.” Your meaning is perfectly clear but the nearness
of the word “they” to “the decomposing dead” suggestes that the decomposing dead
died themselves:

Page 213: “On May 24, 1900 the Adjutant General issued the order” etc.
I found in the Archives Building, in the file on Read, Item No. 325807, records of
the Surgeon General's office that the order was originally issued May 23, apparently.
It was reissued on the 24th. I believe there are some minor differences in the
wording of these two orders. This is of no importance for your book but I will
have to work this out for my own manuscript. I have Sternberg's order of May 23 to
the A.C. I think the latter issued the order May 24.

Page 222: Your imaginary conversation between Reed and Lazear in which
Reed says “I'll have a talk with Carter.” According to General Kean's letter to
me of August 20, 1941, Carter got sick and left Cuba on July 23, before the mos-
quito work really began. General Kean sent me a copy of a letter that he had from
Dr. Carter's daughter dated November 12, 1928 giving this information. In Kean's
letter to me of Sept. 19, 1941 he said that Reed had no connection with Carter
except that he had read a magazine article of Carter's. I should personally imagine
that if Reed did read this article of Carter's and if Carter were still there the
natural thing would have been for Reed to go and see him but I have been unable
to prove to my satisfaction that they ever did actually discuss the matter and I
seem to recall a letter which I believe Thayer of Hopkins wrote Mrs. Lazear in which
he intimated that it was Lazear who had read Carter's paper and appreciated its
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
June 5, 1942
significance. There was no indication that Reed had actually seen Carter. Do
you have the facts right on this point?

Page 233-234: You indicate that when Carroll was inoculated, Lazear
first held the test tube and that Carroll was actually holding it while the
mosquito bit Carroll. I have wondered about that and imagine you based your
remarks on Agramonte's article in the December 15 Scientific Monthly, bottom of
Page 221. I have read something about this somewhere else but can't lay my
hands on it at the moment. The wording was vague and one could not conclude who
was actually holding the tube when the mosquito bit Carroll. Since Lazear at this
time was the one most interested and responsible for these experiments, I advised
Cornwell to have Lazear holding the tube in the Wyeth painting. Are you any more
sure of this story than I am?

Page 239: Speaking of Dean you say, “He had been outside of Camp Columbia
only once in the last fifty-seven days.” On page 210 of Agramonte's article,
Agramonte says that Dean “had not left the military reservation for nearly two
months.” I don't remember the details given by General Truby in his story about
Reed's questioning Dean and offering him money to admit that he had gone out of
the camp. My recollection is that Dean denied he had been out of the camp. Where
did you get the basis for the statement that he had been out once?

Page 251: “The Spaniards, whose only duty was to gather stones off the
ground for a low wall about the Camp” etc. In Agramonte's article, page 234, he
says of the Spanish immigrants, “Their only work was to pick up loose stones from
the ground.” He makes no mention of any stone wall. From various sources I have
heard that a fence was around Camp Lazear but most of the men who lived there whom
I have interviewed do not remember any fence, none have mentioned the wall and
none of the army photographs or those in Kelly's book show any fence or wall.
Are you sure there was one?

Page 267. In interviewed Lambert in Chicago again for the second time about
two weeks ago. He does not believe the part of Andrus' story that Andrus took Reed's
place. I discussed this with General Truby in Washington a couple of weeks ago and
Truby thinks Andrus is correct. Lambert said that they would not have kept Forbes'
blood around for two or three days, waiting for someone to decide to take it. I
reread Andrus' story last night and he does not infer that the blood had been already
taken from Forbes. So far as I can see from your story and that of Andrus, it does
not conflict with the scientific necessity of drawing blood from Forbes during the
first three days of his illness.

div1.p:
I shall be interested to hear when the book will appear. I sincerely hope
that in your foreword you are going to say also how nice Blossom and Walter Reed's
families have been to you even though you found them a little difficult. I am sure
they will be much pleased to have you acknowledge publicly that they are the salt of
the earth and have helped you tremendously even if it isn't quite true.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. psh:ds
